Award.AwardTitle: Vibration-based Damage Detection of Complex Structures with Engineering Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop new vibration-based damage detection methods for complex structures and apply them to engineering systems such as the newly developed space frame wind turbine towers, wind turbine blades, stay cables, and periodic cellular materials. A robust model-based method that uses minimum vibration measurements to detect the locations and extent of damage in structures with different types of joints, including bolted, welded, and riveted joints and interference pins, and in tensioned wire ropes, will be developed. New methods will be developed to model various types of joints and tensioned wire ropes. A damage-sensitive vibration shape (VS)-based method will be developed to detect damage in wind turbine blades using a 3D scanning laser vibrometer.

Monitoring the health of complex structures on a regular basis can provide a sustaining status assessment of structures and avoid their unexpected failure. The model- and VS-based damage detection methods can be used to monitor the health of safety-critical structures such as wind turbine towers and blades, stay cables, and airframes. Various aspects of the research will be adapted for educational purposes to students at all levels, from high school students to Ph.D. students. Some finite element modeling, dynamic testing, and damage detection results will be demonstrated to underserved high school students in a summer educational program to spark their interest in science and engineering. Various symposia on modeling, dynamic testing, and damage detection will be organized to broaden the impact of the research to the scientific community, and to bring together researchers from different scientific societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has supported the research on development of new vibration-based damage detection methods for complex structures and apply them to engineering systems at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. The research proposed new methods to identify different types of damage such as thickness reduction, embedded cracks, and delamination in different structures, such as metal beams and plates and composite beams and plates. Two new non-model-based methods that use measured mode shapes to identify embedded horizontal cracks in beams were developed. A new non­model-­based method that uses principal, mean and Gaussian curvature mode shapes to identify damage in plates was developed. The above proposed methods do not require any a priori information of associated undamaged structures. In addition, a continuously scanning laser Doppler vibrometer (CSLDV) system was developed and can be used for non-contact vibration-based structural damage detection. New methods that use the CSLDV system to detect different kinds of damage were developed.

The new developments of this research can be used to evaluate the current condition of an operating structure before catastrophic failure occurs to the structure since the developed methods do not require any a priori information of associated undamaged structures. The CSLDV system developed in this research can be used to monitor the operating condition of a structure under harsh environment such as high temperature due to its non-contact measurement feature.        

This research has supported several Ph.D. and M.S. students and provided opportunities and experience in areas of vibration measurement, modal analysis, and structural damage detection for them. One Ph.D. student is currently an assistant professor at the University of Cincinnati, and another Ph.D. student is a research engineer at a related comapny. More than ten related papers were published in reputable peer-reviewed journals.
